title: Crankshaft - Removal

body.body: Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
Crankshaft Removal - One use con rods only - PB1; PJ1; PJZ; PM1; PR1; PRB; PRC; PS1; PSB; PSC; PX1; PXB; PXC; PY1; PYB; PYC

For engines built up to engine number AZ7874 and have M8 bolts securing the connecting rod to the crankshaft, for these engines the connecting rod, big end cap, bearings and connecting rod bolts must be replaced if removed.
Reuse of the connecting rods, big end caps, bearings and connecting rod bolts will lead to severe engine damage.
If these engines have M9 bolts securing the connecting rods to the crankshaft, only the M9 bolts and, if required, the bearing shells are to be replaced.
Failure to follow the advice above could cause premature failure of the connecting rods and big end caps will lead to premature engine failure, loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
If required the following parts kits are available.

Detach the camshaft drive chain from the crankshaft sprocket. Support the camshaft drive chain such that it does not fall through the barrels to the cylinder head.
It may be necessary to gently tap the big end cap with a rubber mallet to release the cap.
Remove the connecting rods bolts and the big end caps.
If fitted with M8 bolts, discard the bolts, bearing shells and the big end caps.
If fitted with M9 bolts, discard the bolts and, if required, the bearing shells.
Remove the connecting rods bolts and the big end caps. Discard the bolts.
Detach the connecting rod from the crankshaft.
Carefully remove the crankshaft from the upper crankcase.
